text.p: French glass-maker Saint-Gobain will actively seek acquisitions in the coming years but will be selective by adding to core businesses and will look for areas which add growth, chairman Jean-Louis Beffa said on Tuesday.
The acquisition strategy was "active and selective," he told an analysts' meeting on its 1996 results published in January.

Saint-Gobain's acquisitions will be guided by its aim to be world leader or number two in a given sector, to increase growth, expand its geographical coverage and select areas complementary to existing expertise, he said.

Saint-Gobain's 1996 net cashflow totalled 10.7 billion francs. It had shareholders capital of 62.2 billion francs and net debt of 14.8 percent, giving it a debt/equiity ratio of around 30 percent, he said.
Saint-Gobain could "easily" raise its gearing to 40 percent to take advantage of any opportunities and did not envisage a capital increase, Beffa said.
He said the group acquired companies, such as Poliet bought from Paribas last year, whose growth rate were higher than Saint-Gobain's average rate, he said.
The group is holding to its growth target for Asia, with five billion francs in turnover by 2000 and 20 billion in 2005. That compared to one billion francs a couple of years ago.
Beffa said he had just returned from Latin America and was very confident about the Brazilian economy.
Acquisitions would respect the group's profitability goals. Saint-Gobain's target is operating profit of 20 percent of fixed assets and 10 percent return on equity, based on French accounting rules.
